nodes.text: Subjective, classroom-observation based evaluation can shift the teacher effectiveness distribution by improving teacher skill, effort, or both in ways that persist long-run
Under Cincinnati TES, teachers are more productive during the evaluation year and even more productive in years after evaluation

Empirical strategy: teacher fixed effects comparison of student math achievement before, during, and after TES evaluation using phased-in timing for mid-career 4th–8th grade math teachers (CPS, 2003–2010)
The lasting gains are consistent with an information mechanism (evaluation provides individualized performance information) rather than primarily selection or monetary incentives

Estimated effect: students taught after a teacher's TES evaluation score about 0.112 standard deviations higher in math than when taught by the same teacher before evaluation; during-year gain ~0.052 SD (not always statistically significant)
Heterogeneity: postevaluation improvements are largest for teachers with weakest preevaluation test-score value-added, low TES scores, or large TES score gains during the evaluation year

CPS TES program: year-long observation-based rubric (peer evaluators + administrator), four classroom observations, written feedback and meetings, comprehensive scores in four domains; full TES mainly every five years for veteran teachers

Identification relies on phased-in scheduled timing of first TES evaluation (based on hire year) and teacher fixed effects; controls include student prior achievement and student covariates; experience modeled with a capped quadratic
Event-study evidence shows no clear preexisting upward trend in teacher performance prior to TES evaluation, supporting causal interpretation of postevaluation gains

Key identifying assumption: timing of a teacher's TES evaluation is unrelated to unobserved, time-varying student assignment or teacher performance trends; tests on observables find little evidence of bias
Reading outcomes show no statistically significant TES-related gains, consistent with smaller teacher-driven variation in reading than in math
Conclusion: well-structured subjective evaluation can produce nontransient increases in teacher effectiveness and function as professional development beyond sorting or monetary incentive channels

Limitation and cost considerations: (i) data do not identify exact behavioral changes driving gains; (ii) program costs substantial (approx. $1.8–$2.1M per year, ~7500 per teacher evaluated) and evaluator opportunity costs may reduce classroom production; attrition exists but authors find limited bias from it
